user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleUnload:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleUnload(osal_id_t module_id)
{
    OS_module_internal_record_t *module;
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_token_t            token;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, module_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        module = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_module_table, token);

        /*
         * Only call the implementation if the file was actually loaded.
         * If this is a static module, then this is just a placeholder and
         * it means there was no file actually loaded.
         */
        if (module->module_type == OS_MODULE_TYPE_DYNAMIC)
        {
            return_code = OS_ModuleUnload_Impl(&token);
        }

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleUnload:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_module_internal_record_t OS_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char             module_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    char             file_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    OS_module_type_t module_type;
    uint32           flags;
    cpuaddr          entry_point;
} OS_module_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_ModuleUnload_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                             status = OS_ERROR;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Attempt to close/unload the module
    */
    dlerror();
    if (dlclose(impl->dl_handle) == 0)
    {
        impl->dl_handle = NULL;
        status          = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error unloading shared library: %s\n", dlerror());
    }

    return status;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I reviewed the provided functions and related symbols for modifications of function parameters (per MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8). No code fragment actually assigns to a function parameter variable itself. Specific notes:

- OS_ModuleUnload: The parameter module_id is never assigned to or modified in the function. The local variable token is passed by address to other routines; modifying the object pointed to (via token) is allowed by the rule.

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: The parameter token is a pointer and the function writes into the pointed-to object (token->obj_idx, token->obj_id). These are modifications of the object referred to by the pointer, which the rule permits. The function does not reassign the pointer parameter (there is no statement like token = ...).

- OS_ModuleUnload_Impl: The parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token. The implementation dereferences the pointer to access table entries and modifies fields of the impl record (impl->dl_handle), but it does not modify the pointer parameter itself.

- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete: The function reads and uses token->obj_id and passes token to OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish, but does not reassign the token parameter.

- Macros (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) take the address of their token argument (e.g., &(tok)), but this is taking the address of the expression passed; none of the macro expansions assign to the function parameter variables.

Therefore there are no fragments that violate Rule 17.8 in the supplied code; only allowed modifications of objects pointed to by pointer parameters occur.
